title: Viet Minh
text:
The Việt Minh (; abbreviated from , <a href="Ch%E1%BB%AF%20N%C3%B4m">Chữ Nôm</a> and <a href="H%C3%A1n%20t%E1%BB%B1">Hán tự</a>: ; , ) was a <a href="List%20of%20historical%20separatist%20movements">national independence</a> coalition formed at <a href="P%C3%A1c%20B%C3%B3">Pác Bó</a> by <a href="Ho%20Chi%20Minh">Hồ Chí Minh</a> on May 19, 1941. Also known as the Việt Minh Front, it was created by the <a href="Indochinese%20Communist%20Party">Indochinese Communist Party</a> as a form of <a href="united%20front">united</a> national <a href="front%20organization">front</a> in Vietnam.
The "Việt Nam Độc Lập Đồng Minh Hội" had previously formed in <a href="Nanjing">Nanjing</a>, China, at some point between August 1935 and early 1936 when Vietnamese nationalist parties formed an anti-imperialist <a href="united%20front">united front</a>. This organization soon lapsed into inactivity, only to be revived by the <a href="Indochinese%20Communist%20Party">Communist party Of Indochina</a> (ICP) and Hồ Chí Minh in 1941. The Việt Minh established itself as the only organized anti-French and anti-Japanese resistance group. The Việt Minh initially formed to seek independence for <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> from the <a href="French%20colonial%20empire">French Empire</a>. The United States supported France. When the <a href="Japanese%20occupation%20of%20Vietnam">Japanese occupation</a> began, the Việt Minh opposed Japan with support from the United States and the <a href="Republic%20of%20China%20%281912%E2%80%931949%29">Republic of China</a>. After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the Việt Minh opposed the re-occupation of Vietnam by France, resulting in the <a href="First%20Indochina%20War">Indochina War</a>, and later opposed <a href="South%20Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> and the United States in the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a>.
The political leader and founder of Việt Minh was Hồ Chí Minh. The military leadership was under the command of <a href="V%C3%B5%20Nguy%C3%AAn%20Gi%C3%A1p">Võ Nguyên Giáp</a>. Other founders were <a href="L%C3%AA%20Du%E1%BA%A9n">Lê Duẩn</a> and <a href="Ph%E1%BA%A1m%20V%C4%83n%20%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng">Phạm Văn Đồng</a>.
The "Việt Nam Độc Lập Đồng Minh Hội" is not to be confused with the "Việt Nam Cách Mạng Đồng Minh Hội" (League for the Vietnamese Revolution, abbreviated as "Việt Cách") which was founded by <a href="Nguy%E1%BB%85n%20H%E1%BA%A3i%20Th%E1%BA%A7n">Nguyễn Hải Thần</a>. Viet Cach later joined the Vietnamese National Coalition in 1946.
World War II.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japan</a> occupied <a href="French%20Indochina">French Indochina</a>. As well as fighting the French in the <a href="battles%20of%20Khai%20Phat%20and%20Na%20Ngan">battles of Khai Phat and Na Ngan</a>, the Việt Minh started a <a href="Military%20campaign">campaign</a> against the Japanese. As of the end of 1944, the Việt Minh claimed a membership of 500,000, of which 200,000 were in <a href="Tonkin%20%28French%20protectorate%29">Tonkin</a>, 150,000 in <a href="Annam%20%28French%20protectorate%29">Annam</a>, and 150,000 in <a href="French%20Cochinchina">Cochinchina</a>. Due to their opposition to the Japanese, the Việt Minh received funding from the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="Republic%20of%20China">Republic of China</a>. After the takeover of nationalist organizations and Emperor <a href="B%E1%BA%A3o%20%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i">Bảo Đại</a>'s abdication to the Việt Minh, <a href="Ho%20Chi%20Minh">Hồ Chí Minh</a> declared Vietnam's independence by proclaiming the establishment of the <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a> on September 2, 1945.
First Indochina War.
Within days, the Chinese <a href="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> (Nationalist) Army arrived in Vietnam to supervise the repatriation of the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a>. The Democratic Republic of Vietnam therefore existed only in theory and effectively controlled no territory. A few months later, the Chinese, Vietnamese and French came to a three-way understanding. The French gave up certain rights in China, the Việt Minh agreed to the return of the French in exchange for promises of independence within the <a href="French%20Union">French Union</a>, and the Chinese agreed to leave. Negotiations between the French and Việt Minh broke down quickly. What followed was nearly ten years of war against France. This was known as the <a href="First%20Indochina%20War">First Indochina War</a> or, to the Vietnamese; "the French War".
The Việt Minh, who were short on modern military knowledge, created a military school in <a href="Qu%E1%BA%A3ng%20Ng%C3%A3i%20Province">Quảng Ngãi Province</a> in June 1946. More than 400 Vietnamese were trained by Japanese defectors in this school. These soldiers were considered to be students of the Japanese. Later, some of them fought as generals against the United States in the Vietnam War or, to the Vietnamese; "the American War".
French General <a href="Jean%20%C3%89tienne%20Valluy">Jean Étienne Valluy</a> quickly pushed the Việt Minh out of <a href="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>. His French infantry with armored units went through Hanoi, fighting small battles against isolated Việt Minh groups. The French encircled the Việt Minh base, <a href="Vi%E1%BB%87t%20B%E1%BA%AFc">Việt Bắc</a>, in 1947, but failed to defeat the Việt Minh forces, and had to retreat soon after. The campaign is now widely considered a Việt Minh victory over the well-equipped French force.
The Việt Minh continued fighting against the French until 1949, when the border of China and Vietnam was linked together as a result of the campaign called "Chiến dịch Biên giới" ("Borderland Campaign"). The newly communist <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">People's Republic of China</a> gave the Việt Minh both sheltered bases and heavy weapons with which to fight the French. With the additional weapons, the Việt Minh were able to take control over many rural areas of the country. Soon after that, they began to advance towards the French-occupied areas.
North Vietnam and the end of the Việt Minh.
Following their defeat at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Dien%20Bien%20Phu">Battle of Điện Biên Phủ</a>, the French began negotiations to leave Vietnam. As a result of peace accords worked out at the <a href="Geneva%20Conference%20%281954%29">Geneva Conference</a> in <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a>, Switzerland, Vietnam was divided into <a href="North%20Vietnam">North Vietnam</a> and <a href="South%20Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> at the <a href="17th%20parallel%20north">17th Parallel</a> as a temporary measure until unifying elections could take place in 1956. Transfer of civil administration of North Vietnam to the Việt Minh was given on October 11, 1954. Hồ Chí Minh was appointed <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20North%20Vietnam">Prime Minister of North Vietnam</a>, which would be run as a <a href="socialist%20state">socialist state</a>. <a href="Ngo%20Dinh%20Diem">Ngô Đình Diệm</a>, who was previously appointed Prime Minister of South Vietnam by Emperor <a href="B%E1%BA%A3o%20%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i">Bảo Đại</a>, eventually assumed control of South Vietnam.
The Geneva Accords promised elections in 1956 to determine a national government for a united Vietnam. Neither the United States government nor Ngô Đình Diệm's State of Vietnam signed anything at the 1954 Geneva Conference. With respect to the question of reunification, the non-communist Vietnamese delegation objected strenuously to any division of Vietnam, but lost out when the French accepted the proposal of Việt Minh delegate <a href="Ph%E1%BA%A1m%20V%C4%83n%20%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng">Phạm Văn Đồng</a>, who proposed that Vietnam eventually be united by elections under the supervision of "local commissions". The United States countered with what became known as the "American Plan", with the support of South Vietnam and the United Kingdom. It provided for unification elections under the supervision of the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a>, but was rejected by the Soviet delegation. From his home in France, Vietnamese Emperor <a href="B%E1%BA%A3o%20%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i">Bảo Đại</a> appointed Ngô Đình Diệm as <a href="Leaders%20of%20South%20Vietnam%23Prime%20Ministers">Prime Minister of South Vietnam</a>. With United States support in rigging the referendum of 1955 using secret <a href="Central%20Intelligence%20Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a> (CIA) funding, Diệm removed the Emperor and declared himself the <a href="Leaders%20of%20South%20Vietnam">president</a> of the <a href="South%20Vietnam">Republic of Vietnam</a>.
The United States believed Ho Chi Minh would win the nation wide election proposed at the Geneva Accords. In a secret memorandum, Director of CIA <a href="Allen%20Dulles">Allen Dulles</a> acknowledged that "The evidence [shows] that a majority of the people of Vietnam supported the Viet Minh rebels." Diem refused to hold the elections by citing that the South had not signed and were not bound to the Geneva Accords and that it was impossible to hold free elections in the communist North. Vietnam wide elections never happened and Việt Minh cadres who stayed behind in South Vietnam were activated and launched an insurgency against the government. North Vietnam also occupied portions of Laos to assist in supplying the insurgents known as the <a href="Viet%20Cong">National Liberation Front</a> ("Viet Cong") in South Vietnam. The war gradually escalated into the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Second Indochina War</a>, more commonly known as the "Vietnam War" in the West and the "American War" in Vietnam.
Khmer Việt Minh.
The Khmer Việt Minh were the 3,000 to 5,000 <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Kampuchea">Cambodian communist</a> cadres, left-wing members of the <a href="Khmer%20Issarak">Khmer Issarak</a> movement regrouped in the <a href="United%20Issarak%20Front">United Issarak Front</a> after 1950, most of whom lived in exile in North Vietnam after the <a href="Geneva%20Conference%20%281954%29">1954 Geneva Conference</a>. Khmer Issarak and United Issrak Front were under leadership of <a href="Son%20Ngoc%20Minh">Son Ngoc Minh</a>, <a href="Tou%20Samouth">Tou Samouth</a>, <a href="Sieu%20Heng">Sieu Heng</a>, etc. It was a derogatory term used by <a href="Norodom%20Sihanouk">Norodom Sihanouk</a>, dismissing the Cambodian leftists who had been organizing pro-independence agitations in alliance with the Vietnamese. Sihanouk's public criticism and mockery of the Khmer Issarak had the damaging effect of increasing the power of the hardline, anti-Vietnamese, but also anti-monarchist, members of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Kampuchea">Communist Party of Kampuchea</a> (CPK), led by <a href="Pol%20Pot">Pol Pot</a>.
The Khmer Issarak and United Issarak Front were instrumental in the foundation of the <a href="Kampuchean%20United%20Front%20for%20National%20Salvation">Cambodian Salvation Front</a> (FUNSK) in 1978. The FUNSK invaded Cambodia along with the <a href="People%27s%20Army%20of%20Vietnam">Vietnamese Army</a> and overthrew the <a href="Democratic%20Kampuchea">Democratic Kampuchea</a> Pol Pot state. Many of the Khmer Việt Minh had married Vietnamese women during their long exile in Vietnam.
Laotian Việt Minh.
<a href="Lao%20Issara">Lao Issara</a> ("Free Laos") is a political & military organization of Laotian communists, led by <a href="Phetsarath">Phetsarath</a>, <a href="Souphanouvong">Souphanouvong</a>, <a href="Kaysone%20Phomvihane">Kaysone Phomvihane</a>, <a href="Phoumi%20Vongvichit">Phoumi Vongvichit</a> Lao Issara received training and supports from <a href="Vi%E1%BB%87t%20Minh">Việt Minh</a>. Under French intervention, Lao Issara was split into non-communists and communists. Laotian non-communists under leadership of Pretsarath later established the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Laos">Kingdom of Laos</a> which is part of the <a href="French%20Union">French Union</a>.
However Laotian communists rejected the French offer and fought side by side with Vietnamese communists during the <a href="First%20Indochina%20War">First Indochina War</a>. In 1950 Lao Issara was renamed to <a href="Pathet%20Lao">Pathet Lao</a> ("Laos Nation") under leadership of <a href="Souphanouvong">Souphanouvong</a>, <a href="Kaysone%20Phomvihane">Kaysone Phomvihane</a>, <a href="Phoumi%20Vongvichit">Phoumi Vongvichit</a>, etc.
